title: Hosea Chapter 6 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Hosea chapter 6 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Hosea Chapter 6 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Hosea Chapter 6.

questions.question: According to Hosea 6:1, what will the LORD do after He has torn and smitten?
options: He will heal us and bind us up
questions.correctAnswer: He will heal us and bind us up
questions.explanation: Hosea 6:1 states that the LORD has torn and smitten but will heal us and bind us up.

questions.question: In Hosea 6:2, on which day will the LORD raise us up?
questions.correctAnswer: The third day
questions.explanation: Hosea 6:2 says that on the third day He will raise us up.

questions.question: According to Hosea 6:3, what is the LORD compared to when He comes unto us?
options: Rain, the latter and former rain unto the earth
questions.correctAnswer: Rain, the latter and former rain unto the earth
questions.explanation: Hosea 6:3 compares the LORD's coming unto us as the rain, the latter and former rain unto the earth.

questions.question: What is Ephraim’s goodness compared to in Hosea 6:4?
options: A morning cloud and early dew
questions.correctAnswer: A morning cloud and early dew
questions.explanation: Hosea 6:4 compares Ephraim's goodness to a morning cloud and early dew that soon disappears.

questions.question: How has God dealt with the people according to Hosea 6:5?
options: He hewed them by the prophets and slain them by the words of His mouth
He gave them gold and silver
questions.correctAnswer: He hewed them by the prophets and slain them by the words of His mouth
questions.explanation: Hosea 6:5 explains that God has hewed them by the prophets and slain them by His words.

questions.question: What does God desire more than burnt offerings according to Hosea 6:6?
questions.correctAnswer: Mercy and knowledge of God
questions.explanation: Hosea 6:6 clearly states God desires mercy and knowledge of Him more than sacrifice or burnt offerings.

questions.question: According to Hosea 6:7, how have the people behaved regarding the covenant?
options: They have transgressed the covenant and dealt treacherously
They have kept the covenant faithfully
They were unaware of the covenant
They renewed the covenant with joy
questions.correctAnswer: They have transgressed the covenant and dealt treacherously
questions.explanation: Hosea 6:7 says the people have transgressed the covenant and dealt treacherously against God.

questions.question: Where is described as a city of those who work iniquity in Hosea 6:8?
questions.correctAnswer: Gilead
questions.explanation: Hosea 6:8 describes Gilead as a city of those that work iniquity and is polluted with blood.

questions.question: In Hosea 6:9, who are said to murder by consent?
questions.correctAnswer: The company of priests
questions.explanation: Hosea 6:9 states that the company of priests murder in the way by consent.

questions.question: What horrible thing has been seen in the house of Israel according to Hosea 6:10?
options: The whoredom of Ephraim and defilement of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: The whoredom of Ephraim and defilement of Israel
questions.explanation: Hosea 6:10 describes an horrible thing seen in Israel: the whoredom of Ephraim and defilement of Israel.

questions.question: What has God set for Judah when He returned the captivity of His people in Hosea 6:11?
questions.correctAnswer: A harvest
questions.explanation: Hosea 6:11 mentions that God has set a harvest for Judah upon returning the captivity of His people.

questions.question: True or False: Hosea 6:6 states that God desires burnt offerings more than mercy.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Hosea 6:6 states that God desires mercy and knowledge of Him more than burnt offerings.

questions.question: True or False: Hosea 6:2 indicates that after two days God will revive us and on the third day raise us up.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Hosea 6:2 explains that after two days He will revive us and on the third day He will raise us up.

questions.question: True or False: According to Hosea 6:4, the goodness of Ephraim is enduring and like a strong mountain.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Hosea 6:4 compares Ephraim's goodness to a morning cloud and early dew, which quickly goes away, not enduring like a strong mountain.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Hosea 6:3: "Then shall we know, if we follow on to know the LORD: his going forth is prepared as the _______; and he shall come unto us as the rain."
questions.correctAnswer: morning
questions.explanation: Hosea 6:3 states that his going forth is prepared as the morning.

medium.title: Hosea Chapter 6 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Hosea Chapter 6 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on Hosea 6:1-2, what biblical truth would you share about God's response to our repentance?
options: God will heal and revive us after we return to Him.
God will immediately punish us without mercy.
God expects us to fix ourselves before He intervenes.
God only heals those who never sin.
questions.correctAnswer: God will heal and revive us after we return to Him.
questions.explanation: Hosea 6:1-2 teaches that when we return to the LORD, He who has torn will heal us, and after two days He will revive us, raising us up to live in His sight. This emphasizes God's mercy and restoration upon repentance.

questions.question: How does Hosea 6:3 teach us about the importance of seeking to know the LORD in our daily lives?
options: Following on to know the LORD brings steady, life-giving blessings like the morning and rain.
Knowing the LORD is unnecessary if we do good works.
The LORD is unpredictable and cannot be known.
Seeking the LORD is only for priests and prophets.
questions.correctAnswer: Following on to know the LORD brings steady, life-giving blessings like the morning and rain.
questions.explanation: Hosea 6:3 explains that if we diligently seek to know the LORD, His coming will be sure and life-giving, like the morning dawn and the refreshing former and latter rain, symbolizing consistent spiritual nourishment.

questions.question: What lesson about faithfulness and consistency in our relationship with God is taught in Hosea 6:4?
options: God desires steadfast goodness, not fleeting devotion like a morning cloud.
God prefers occasional worship over daily commitment.
A brief time of devotion is enough for God.
God values sacrifices more than ongoing faithfulness.
questions.correctAnswer: God desires steadfast goodness, not fleeting devotion like a morning cloud.
questions.explanation: Hosea 6:4 uses the metaphor of goodness like a morning cloud and early dew that vanish quickly to show that God desires lasting faithfulness rather than temporary or superficial devotion.

questions.question: According to Hosea 6:5, how does God use His prophets and His Word in the life of His people?
options: God disciplines His people through the prophets and His spoken judgments.
God ignores the people's sins and offers no correction.
God only rewards people without warning.
God's words are optional and have no real effect.
questions.correctAnswer: God disciplines His people through the prophets and His spoken judgments.
questions.explanation: Hosea 6:5 states that God 'hewed them by the prophets' and 'slain them by the words of my mouth,' indicating His use of prophetic messages and judgments as disciplinary tools to guide His people back to righteousness.

questions.question: What does Hosea 6:6 teach about God's priorities in worship and obedience?
options: God desires mercy and knowledge of Him more than sacrifices and burnt offerings.
God values sacrifices above all else.
Obedience is less important than ritual observance.
God is indifferent to human actions.
questions.correctAnswer: God desires mercy and knowledge of Him more than sacrifices and burnt offerings.
questions.explanation: Hosea 6:6 clearly expresses that God values acts of mercy and a true knowledge of Him over ritual sacrifices, highlighting the importance of heartfelt obedience and relationship over mere religious formalities.

questions.question: A believer struggles with temptation to compromise their integrity. How does Hosea 6:7 warn about the consequences of breaking God's covenant?
options: Breaking the covenant is treacherous and displeasing to God.
God will overlook covenant breaches without consequence.
Covenant breaking is acceptable if done secretly.
Only priests are bound by God's covenant.
questions.correctAnswer: Breaking the covenant is treacherous and displeasing to God.
questions.explanation: Hosea 6:7 states that the people 'like men have transgressed the covenant' and dealt treacherously against God, indicating that covenant faithfulness is vital and breaking it is a serious offense.

questions.question: How does Hosea 6:8 illustrate the impact of sin on a community, particularly regarding honesty and integrity?
options: Sin pollutes a community and leads to iniquity and bloodshed.
Sin has no effect on community life.
Only individuals suffer when they sin, not communities.
Sin can be ignored if it benefits the community.
questions.correctAnswer: Sin pollutes a community and leads to iniquity and bloodshed.
questions.explanation: Hosea 6:8 describes Gilead as a city of those who work iniquity and is polluted with blood, showing how sin damages the moral fabric and peace of a community.

questions.question: What warning does Hosea 6:9 give about leaders and those in spiritual authority?
options: Some priests commit lewdness and murder by consent, betraying their sacred trust.
Priests always lead righteously without fault.
Spiritual leaders are exempt from judgment.
Leaders should focus only on rituals, not behavior.
questions.correctAnswer: Some priests commit lewdness and murder by consent, betraying their sacred trust.
questions.explanation: Hosea 6:9 reveals that some priests act corruptly, waiting like robbers and murdering by consent, signifying a betrayal of their responsibility to lead with integrity.

questions.question: Based on Hosea 6:10, what does God reveal about the spiritual condition of Israel?
options: Israel is defiled by whoredom, indicating unfaithfulness to God.
Israel is free from sin and rebellion.
Israel's sins are hidden and unknown.
questions.correctAnswer: Israel is defiled by whoredom, indicating unfaithfulness to God.
questions.explanation: Hosea 6:10 states that there is 'the whoredom of Ephraim' and that Israel is defiled, symbolizing spiritual adultery and unfaithfulness to God.

questions.question: How does Hosea 6:11 encourage believers about God's plan for restoration and blessing?
options: God sets a harvest for His people when He restores them from captivity.
God abandons His people completely after failure.
Restoration is impossible once captivity occurs.
Blessings come only through human effort.
questions.correctAnswer: God sets a harvest for His people when He restores them from captivity.
questions.explanation: Hosea 6:11 indicates that God prepares a harvest for Judah upon restoration from captivity, symbolizing hope and blessing following repentance and deliverance.

questions.question: True or False: Hosea 6:6 teaches that God desires burnt offerings more than mercy and knowledge of Him.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Hosea 6:6 explicitly states that God desires mercy, not sacrifice, and knowledge of God more than burnt offerings, emphasizing the importance of compassion and relationship over ritual.

questions.question: True or False: According to Hosea 6:1, God will not heal His people after they have been torn and smitten.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Hosea 6:1 promises that though God has torn and smitten His people, He will heal and bind them up, showing His readiness to restore upon their return.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Hosea 6:3 says, 'Then shall we know, if we follow on to know the LORD: his going forth is prepared as the _______; and he shall come unto us as the rain.'
questions.correctAnswer: morning
questions.explanation: Hosea 6:3 uses the metaphor of the LORD's going forth being prepared as the morning, symbolizing certainty and hope like the dawn, encouraging believers to seek Him.

questions.question: How does Hosea 6:7 challenge believers regarding their commitment to God's covenant?
options: It warns that transgressing the covenant is an act of treachery against God.
It encourages casual observance of the covenant.
It states that the covenant is optional for believers.
It suggests that only leaders need to keep the covenant.
questions.correctAnswer: It warns that transgressing the covenant is an act of treachery against God.
questions.explanation: Hosea 6:7 highlights that the people have dealt treacherously by breaking the covenant, reminding believers of the seriousness of covenant faithfulness.

questions.question: According to Hosea 6:9, what is the consequence of priests committing lewdness and murder by consent?
options: Spiritual leadership is corrupted and harms the community.
The community is unaffected by leaders’ sins.
Such behavior is rewarded by God.
Priests are exempt from judgment for their actions.
questions.correctAnswer: Spiritual leadership is corrupted and harms the community.
questions.explanation: Hosea 6:9 describes priests acting like robbers and committing harmful acts, which corrupts their leadership and negatively impacts the entire community.

hard.title: Hosea Chapter 6 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Hosea Chapter 6.

questions.question: In Hosea 6:2, what is the significance of the phrase 'in the third day he will raise us up' in relation to biblical typology?
options: It foreshadows the resurrection of Jesus Christ
It refers to the restoration of Israel after exile
It symbolizes the annual festival of Passover
It denotes the third day of creation
questions.correctAnswer: It foreshadows the resurrection of Jesus Christ
questions.explanation: Hosea 6:2's mention of revival 'in the third day' is commonly understood as a typological foreshadowing of Jesus Christ's resurrection on the third day, linking Old Testament prophecy to New Testament fulfillment.

questions.question: Which literary device is primarily used in Hosea 6:1 with the phrases 'he hath torn, and he will heal us; he hath smitten, and he will bind us up'?
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism
questions.explanation: Hosea 6:1 employs parallelism, a common Hebrew poetic device that balances contrasting ideas in a symmetrical structure: the LORD's disciplinary actions followed by His healing and restoration.

questions.question: According to Hosea 6:6, what does God desire more than burnt offerings?
options: Mercy and the knowledge of God
questions.correctAnswer: Mercy and the knowledge of God
questions.explanation: Hosea 6:6 clearly states that God desires 'mercy, and not sacrifice; and the knowledge of God more than burnt offerings,' emphasizing ethical devotion over ritual.

questions.question: How does Hosea 6:3 use the imagery of rain to describe the Lord's coming?
options: As the latter and former rain to the earth
As a fire consuming the land
questions.correctAnswer: As the latter and former rain to the earth
questions.explanation: Hosea 6:3 employs agricultural imagery of 'the latter and former rain' which were vital for crops, symbolizing God's faithful and timely provision and blessing.

questions.question: What does the 'morning cloud' and 'early dew' symbolize in Hosea 6:4 regarding Ephraim's goodness?
questions.correctAnswer: Transience and inconsistency
questions.explanation: Hosea 6:4 compares Ephraim's goodness to a 'morning cloud' and 'early dew' that disappear quickly, symbolizing their fleeting and unreliable faithfulness.

questions.question: In Hosea 6:5, what is the method God uses to 'hew' and 'slay' the people?
options: By the prophets and the words of His mouth
questions.correctAnswer: By the prophets and the words of His mouth
questions.explanation: Hosea 6:5 highlights that God's judgment comes through prophetic warnings and His spoken words, indicating the role of prophecy as divine discipline.

questions.question: What covenant violation is identified in Hosea 6:7 that parallels themes in Jeremiah and Ezekiel?
questions.correctAnswer: Treachery and breaking the covenant
questions.explanation: Hosea 6:7 accuses Israel of covenant treachery, a theme echoed in Jeremiah and Ezekiel where Israel's faithlessness leads to judgment and exile.

questions.question: True or False: Hosea 6:8 describes Gilead as a city characterized by innocence and peace.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Hosea 6:8 states that Gilead is a city of those who work iniquity and is polluted with blood, indicating violence and corruption.

questions.question: In Hosea 6:9, what wrongdoing is attributed to the priests?
options: They murder in the way by consent and commit lewdness
They neglect the teaching of the law
questions.correctAnswer: They murder in the way by consent and commit lewdness
questions.explanation: Hosea 6:9 accuses the priests of complicity in murder and sexual immorality, highlighting religious corruption.

questions.question: What does the 'whoredom of Ephraim' metaphor in Hosea 6:10 symbolize?
questions.correctAnswer: Spiritual unfaithfulness and idolatry
questions.explanation: Hosea 6:10 uses 'whoredom' as a metaphor for Ephraim's idolatry and betrayal of covenantal faithfulness.

questions.question: How does Hosea 6:11 connect to the historical context of Israel's captivity?
options: It speaks of a future harvest upon returning from captivity
It describes the beginning of the exile
It recounts the destruction of Jerusalem
It predicts the rise of Assyria
questions.correctAnswer: It speaks of a future harvest upon returning from captivity
questions.explanation: Hosea 6:11 anticipates a restoration and fruitful harvest coinciding with the return from exile, reflecting hope amid judgment.

questions.question: Which Hebrew concept underlying Hosea 6:6 emphasizes ethical devotion over ritual sacrifice?
questions.correctAnswer: Chesed (mercy/kindness)
questions.explanation: The term 'mercy' in Hosea 6:6 corresponds to the Hebrew concept of chesed, emphasizing covenantal love and loyalty above ritual offerings.

questions.question: How does the phrase 'his going forth is prepared as the morning' in Hosea 6:3 relate to the theme of divine faithfulness?
options: It symbolizes the certainty and regularity of God's actions
It refers to the unpredictability of God's judgment
It reflects the fleeting nature of God's mercy
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes the certainty and regularity of God's actions
questions.explanation: Hosea 6:3 likens God's coming to the morning, highlighting the dependable and faithful nature of God's promises.

questions.question: In the context of ancient Near Eastern culture, what does the metaphor of 'binding up' in Hosea 6:1 imply about God's relationship with Israel?
options: God as healer restoring the people
God as king ruling with authority
questions.correctAnswer: God as healer restoring the people
questions.explanation: The metaphor of 'binding up' wounds in Hosea 6:1 portrays God as a compassionate healer who restores Israel after discipline.

questions.question: True or False: Hosea 6:7 indicates that Israel's covenant violation was similar to human treachery.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Hosea 6:7 states that 'they like men have transgressed the covenant,' indicating a human-like betrayal of God's covenant.

theological.title: Hosea Chapter 6 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Hosea Chapter 6 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Hosea 6:1, what is the reason given to return to the LORD?
options: Because He has torn and will heal us
questions.correctAnswer: Because He has torn and will heal us
questions.explanation: Hosea 6:1 invites a return to the LORD because He has torn but will heal, showing both His judgment and mercy. This is consistent with God's nature of righteous discipline followed by restoration (Psalm 147:3, Isaiah 53:5, Jeremiah 30:17, 2 Corinthians 12:9).

questions.question: In Hosea 6:2, what does God promise to do after two days?
questions.correctAnswer: Revive us
questions.explanation: Hosea 6:2 states that after two days God will revive us, and on the third day raise us up to live in His sight, which echoes resurrection themes seen in Jonah 1:17, Psalm 16:10, and is prophetically fulfilled in Christ's resurrection (Matthew 12:40, 1 Corinthians 15:4).

questions.question: Hosea 6:3 suggests that knowing the LORD is like what natural phenomena?
questions.correctAnswer: The morning and the rain
questions.explanation: Hosea 6:3 compares knowing the LORD to His coming forth like morning light and rain that refreshes the earth, symbolizing God's faithfulness and renewal (James 1:17, Isaiah 55:10-11, Deuteronomy 33:14, Matthew 5:45).

questions.question: What does Hosea 6:4 say about the goodness of Ephraim and Judah?
options: It is like a morning cloud and early dew that disappears
It is as strong as a mountain
It is like a flowing river
questions.correctAnswer: It is like a morning cloud and early dew that disappears
questions.explanation: Hosea 6:4 critiques the fleeting nature of Israel's goodness, comparing it to transient morning cloud and dew, illustrating human fickleness contrasted with God's steadfastness (Psalm 90:5-6, James 1:11, Isaiah 40:6-8, Matthew 6:19-20).

questions.question: According to Hosea 6:5, by what means has God judged Israel?
options: By the prophets and words of His mouth
questions.correctAnswer: By the prophets and words of His mouth
questions.explanation: Hosea 6:5 explains God's judgment through the prophets and His spoken word, showing divine communication as a means of correction, consistent with the prophetic role in Scripture (Deuteronomy 18:18, Jeremiah 1:9, Ezekiel 3:4, Hebrews 1:1-2).

questions.question: What does Hosea 6:6 express as more desired by God than sacrifice?
questions.correctAnswer: Mercy and knowledge of God
questions.explanation: Hosea 6:6 reveals God's preference for mercy and knowledge of Him rather than ritual sacrifices, emphasizing relational faith over ceremonial acts (Micah 6:6-8, Matthew 9:13, Hebrews 10:22, Psalm 51:16-17).

questions.question: What covenant violation is described in Hosea 6:7?
options: Transgressing the covenant and treachery against God
questions.correctAnswer: Transgressing the covenant and treachery against God
questions.explanation: Hosea 6:7 accuses Israel of covenant breach and treachery, highlighting human sinfulness and unfaithfulness, a persistent biblical theme (Jeremiah 11:10, Ezekiel 16:59, Romans 3:23, Hebrews 8:9).

questions.question: Hosea 6:8 calls Gilead a city of what?
options: Those who work iniquity and are polluted with blood
questions.correctAnswer: Those who work iniquity and are polluted with blood
questions.explanation: Hosea 6:8 describes Gilead as a place characterized by iniquity and bloodshed, illustrating societal corruption and moral decay (Genesis 34:25, Judges 20:48, Jeremiah 22:3, Isaiah 1:15).

questions.question: What wrongdoing is attributed to the priests in Hosea 6:9?
questions.correctAnswer: Murder by consent and lewdness
questions.explanation: Hosea 6:9 condemns the priests for collusion in violence and immoral acts, pointing to religious leadership's corruption, which contradicts their sacred duties (Ezekiel 22:25-26, Jeremiah 23:14, Malachi 2:8, Matthew 23:27-28).

questions.question: What horrible thing does Hosea 6:10 say has been seen in the house of Israel?
options: The whoredom of Ephraim and defilement of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: The whoredom of Ephraim and defilement of Israel
questions.explanation: Hosea 6:10 describes spiritual adultery and defilement, symbolizing Israel's idolatry and unfaithfulness to God, a major prophetic theme (Jeremiah 3:1, Ezekiel 16:15, Revelation 2:20, 1 Corinthians 6:18).

questions.question: What does Hosea 6:11 promise for Judah?
options: An harvest when captivity is returned
questions.correctAnswer: An harvest when captivity is returned
questions.explanation: Hosea 6:11 offers hope by promising Judah a harvest upon return from captivity, reflecting restoration after judgment (Jeremiah 29:14, Ezekiel 37:12-14, Isaiah 61:1-3, Zechariah 8:12).

questions.question: How does Hosea 6:3 describe the LORD’s coming to His people?
options: As the latter and former rain to the earth
questions.correctAnswer: As the latter and former rain to the earth
questions.explanation: Hosea 6:3 likens God's coming to seasonal rains that nourish the earth, symbolizing blessing and renewal, consistent with God's sustaining grace (Deuteronomy 11:14, Joel 2:23, James 5:7, Psalm 65:9-10).

questions.question: What does Hosea 6:6 imply about the relationship between mercy and sacrifice?
options: Mercy is more desired than sacrifice
Sacrifice is more important than mercy
Neither mercy nor sacrifice is important
questions.correctAnswer: Mercy is more desired than sacrifice
questions.explanation: In Hosea 6:6, God expresses a preference for mercy over sacrifice, emphasizing internal righteousness over external ritual, a teaching echoed by Jesus (Matthew 9:13, 12:7) and the prophets (Micah 6:6-8, Psalm 51:16-17).

questions.question: Which group is particularly condemned for their treachery in Hosea 6:9?
questions.correctAnswer: The priests
questions.explanation: Hosea 6:9 condemns the priests for participating in murder and lewdness by consent, highlighting religious leaders' failure to uphold God's standards (Ezekiel 22:26, Jeremiah 23:11, Malachi 2:1-9, Matthew 23:13-15).

questions.question: What role do the 'prophets' play according to Hosea 6:5?
options: They are instruments of God's judgment
questions.correctAnswer: They are instruments of God's judgment
questions.explanation: Hosea 6:5 describes prophets as those through whom God executes judgment by His words, consistent with their biblical role to call Israel to repentance (Amos 3:7, Jeremiah 1:17, Ezekiel 3:4, Hebrews 1:1).
